title: Gaps in Arms Supplies to Ukraine Point to Countries’ Divergent Strategies
abstract: Beyond logistical issues, the uneven flow of arms to Ukraine hints at differences among allies about whether Russia should be punished or eventually accommodated.

multimedia.caption: Ukrainian troops fired a a U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer at Russian positions last month in the Donetsk region.
Ukrainian troops fired a a U.S.-supplied M777 howitzer at Russian positions last month in the Donetsk region.

title: A New Palestinian Leader Rises in the West Bank. He’s Very Unpopular.
abstract: Hussein al-Sheikh is considered a possible successor to Mahmoud Abbas, 87, the Palestinian Authority president. But as a liaison to Israel, some critics call him a “spokesman of the occupation.”

multimedia.caption: Hussein al-Sheikh has become the focus of a debate among Palestinians about the vision and legitimacy of their leaders.

title: Smile or Be Disciplined, Mayors Warn City Workers
abstract: “Frowning is not allowed in the municipality!” said the mayor of Mulanay in the Philippines. Many residents applauded his new policy.
byline: By John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez

multimedia.caption: Failure to smile could now cost employees of the Philippine town of Mulanay their jobs, says Mayor Aristotle Aguirre. But he’d prefer “a simple censure” or sensitivity training.
Failure to smile could now cost employees of the Philippine town of Mulanay their jobs, says Mayor Aristotle Aguirre. But he’d prefer “a simple censure” or sensitivity training.

title: Italy’s Unity Government Teeters, as Mario Draghi Offers to Resign
abstract: The country’s president refused to accept the prime minister’s resignation, leaving the country in political limbo.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Mario Draghi, center, speaking at the Italian Senate, in Rome in June. This week, he said, “A government does not work with ultimatums.”
Prime Minister Mario Draghi, center, speaking at the Italian Senate, in Rome in June. This week, he said, “A government does not work with ultimatums.”

title: Sri Lanka’s President Resigns After Months of Protest
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka submitted his resignation by email from Singapore, although the political uncertainty continues.
byline: By Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal

multimedia.caption: Protesters in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Thursday night cheered the news that the country’s president had resigned.

title: Biden’s Saudi Lesson: The Only Path Runs Through M.B.S.
abstract: President Biden tried to isolate Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over human rights abuses. Now, the United States needs Saudi Arabia, and Mr. Biden is about to visit.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: A mural of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. Concerns over oil prices and Iran’s nuclear capabilities are forcing the president to seek help from the kingdom and its de facto ruler.

title: France Faces a Shortage of Mustard, Its Uniquely Beloved Condiment
abstract: A perfect storm of climate change, a European war and Covid have left the French scrambling for alternatives.

multimedia.caption: Mustard on sale in Dijon, France, last year. While Dijon mustard is as irreplaceable as it is indispensable, lately French diners have had to do without.

title: Ex-Iranian Official Convicted by Swedish Court for Prison Executions
abstract: Swedish prosecutors pursued the case against the official, Hamid Noury, for crimes in his homeland, and he was sentenced to life for his role in the 1988 deaths of thousands of opposition members.
byline: By Christina Anderson and Farnaz Fassihi

title: Priests Once Aligned With Russia Come Under Suspicion in Ukraine
abstract: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church was once a dominant force in the country, but now officials suspect that some priests may be collaborating with Russia.

title: A Combative Macron Seeks to Dispel Worries of Second-Term Drift
abstract: In a televised Bastille Day interview, the French president sought to reassure a country buffeted by rising inflation, scorching temperatures and uncertain political waters.

multimedia.caption: President Emmanuel Macron at the annual Bastille Day military parade in Paris. For the second time in his presidency, he gave a traditional Bastille Day televised interview.
President Emmanuel Macron at the annual Bastille Day military parade in Paris. For the second time in his presidency, he gave a traditional Bastille Day televised interview.

title: With Prices Soaring, I.M.F. and Pakistan Reach Deal to Revive Loan Program
abstract: The long-awaited agreement could pave the way for the release of $1.17 billion to Pakistan as the country grapples with high inflation and political instability.

multimedia.caption: Supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan’s political party protesting against rising inflation in Karachi, Pakistan, last month.

title: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to Sexual Assault
abstract: The Oscar-winning actor will face a trial in June 2023 — a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case reaching that stage in Britain.

multimedia.caption: The actor Kevin Spacey arrived for his appearance at the Old Bailey, a courthouse in central London.

abstract: Demonstrators express frustration with Washington’s support for Israel and the Biden administration’s policies toward Palestinians.

title: The many parties involved complicate war crimes investigations.
abstract: Russian attacks on civilians have underscored the need to hold war crimes to account. But the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned against a “stampede” of investigations.
byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

multimedia.caption: Thursday’s rocket strike on Vinnytsia, Ukraine, was the latest Russian attack that seemed to target a civilian area of a Ukrainian city.

abstract: Russian strikes on Ukrainian civilians.

title: Sharp Drop in Childhood Vaccinations Threatens Millions of Lives
abstract: Pandemic lockdowns, misinformation campaigns, conflicts, climate crises and other problems diverted resources and contributed to the largest backslide in routine immunization in 30 years.

multimedia.caption: Polio vaccinations at a bus station in Jammu, India, in February. India, Nigeria, Indonesia, Ethiopia and the Philippines recorded the highest numbers of children who had missed out on vaccines.

title: Stubborn Divisions on Iran Don’t Cool Biden’s Warm Welcome in Israel
abstract: Amid declarations of the strong friendship between Israel and the United States, the differing approaches to the best way to stop Iran’s nuclear program were evident on Mr. Biden’s trip to Jerusalem.

multimedia.caption: President Biden and Prime Minister Yair Lapid of Israel at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Jerusalem on Thursday.

title: Strikes on Civilians Deep in Ukraine Show Russia’s Lethal Reach
abstract: Missiles struck Vinnytsia, hundreds of miles from the front lines, and other cities, claiming dozens of lives, as Russia keeps up pressure despite pausing its eastern offensive.
byline: By Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson

title: Israeli Security Officials Are Divided Over Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Though the government has opposed any deal with Iran, officials in the Israeli military and its intelligence wing are arguing in favor of a treaty.

title: In an era of alphabet soup diplomacy, Biden is adding ingredients.
abstract: Unsettled times have brought a proliferation of new clusters of various countries, and the acronyms that come with them.

title: The W.H.O. warns against ‘apathy’ in efforts to contain Covid in Africa.
abstract: The warning came two days after the W.H.O., a United Nations agency, declared that Covid-19 was still a global public health emergency that was not going anywhere.

multimedia.caption: W.H.O. officials warned of the danger of relaxing public health precautions for events that draw large crowds. Fans filled a stadium in Pretoria, South Africa, for a rugby test match on July 2.

abstract: Israel’s biggest sporting event, which President Biden is scheduled to attend on Thursday evening, is often referred to as the Jewish Olympics.

title: What is the I2U2?
abstract: The name of a new partnership between India, Israel, the United Arab Emirates and the United States refers to the first letters of the four countries’ names in English.

abstract: The U.S. president has often spoken fondly of Israel’s former prime minister, but relations between the two have also had low points.
